The only negative is that the museum is only open Thursdays through Saturdays during April through October.
Amazing collection of GAR Memorablia, civil war relics, pictures and display badges from GAR conventions.
We went to this museum because it was something we had not seen and my husband is into the Civil War.

We thoroughly enjoyed going through and looking at all the items in all the cases. We especially liked the gavels that were made out of trees from different battlefields. We been to several battlefields so it was fun to associate what we knew with the gavels. 

We talked with one guide about a photo of civil war veterans taken close to the 50th anniversary of the battle of Shiloh. It was then that we realized my husband was at the point that it’s been 50 years since he served in Vietnam. Guess we are getting old!

Just a great little quick museum. Well worth the time for what these boys gave up for us.

My husband and I went to visit this museum not realizing it was closed that day.  However, the curator saw out the back door and invited us in. It was a very interesting museum and he was very helpful about explaining things and showing us some very rare items including a diary.  We were so happy to have had a chance to visit as we are from Montana and probably won't be back.  It doesn't take too long to see everything and isn't far from the Lincoln sites.  I highly recommend it if you have an interest in the Civil War.

name: Union Station - Lincoln from History to Hollywood
address: 500 E Madison St Historic Union Station
reviews: Train station with Lincoln memorabilia from Spielberg movie. Across the street from the Lincoln Museum and Library. Don't miss the statues in the small park behind the train station.

Don't pay extra at the Lincoln Presidential Library to see the Spiegler film "exhibit."  It takes all of 5 minutes and is not worth the money.  The Depot used to have a moving audio on Lincoln's farewell speech as he left to assume the Presidency, but no more.

Don't pay extra at the Lincoln Presidential Library to see the Spiegler film "exhibit."  It takes all of 5 minutes and is not worth the money.  The Depot used to have a moving audio on Lincoln's farewell speech as he left to assume the Presidency, but no more.
The exterior is beautiful.  The interior is worth your while.  Usually, I don't like to read a lot of plaques on display walls.  But here, I wanted to read everything and absorb each artifact.
We didn't have time to go inside the station (same ticket used from the museum), but the exterior of the building is very well remodeled to its original view.  There are train exhibits inside.
There are historical items and pictures of Lincoln and family.  A miniature of his funeral trainand other train memobilia are displayed.  Only spent about 15 minutes but interesting.
Not far from the Old State capitol you can easily locate Union Station and its pleasant park in front, its a charming area of Springfield and well worth a wander, lovely building.
A few model train exhibits and history of the railroad but not much else.  It was included with our admission to the Lincoln Museum so we breezed through.  Would not have paid to see it otherwise.

name: Elijah Iles House
reviews: I've been a volunteer at the Iles house.  This house is not always open because it is all charity and volunteers.  Iles was a friend and neighbor of Abraham Lincoln and donated property for the Home of the Friendless.  Greatly and lovingly maintained with "Summer Porch Chats" on interesting topics.

My wife and I lucked out in being able to see the Iles house after visiting the Lincoln Home site just two blocks away.  The house is only open two days a week, from noon to 4:00, since it is operated by a private foundation with docent guides.  Our docent, Connie Sims, was excellent.  The restoration has concentrated on the structure itself, not furniture and furnishings, though a few pieces of original furniture and paintings are on display.  A collection of antique watches is housed in the basement.

We decided to visit here after we found that another place was closed.  It was a great choice.  When we got there Mr. Lincoln had just started talking about Gettysburg  We sat in on it and were very impressed with the talk.  The impersonator, Fritz, was fantastic.  He resembled Lincoln more than any we have seen.  Right down to the mole on his right side.  He does this at many of the Lincoln sites during the week.  There is a brochure with the times and places.  Our tour guide was Larry.  What a wealth of info.  We must have been there for at least 3 hours.  Not only did he talk about Lincoln and the place we were visiting but he talked about many other things and we added a lot to the conversation.  We then went downstairs to see the clock/watch exhibit.  The person putting it on, Farrell Gay, was there and we got a lot of info.  On our way back to our camper we happened upon the old Illinois watch factory he had told us about.  This is a must stop for anyone visiting Springfield, Il.
parking was challenging, but it was well worth the stop on our trip.  room had original items, you could almost FEEL the past.

My wife and I lucked out in being able to see the Iles house after visiting the Lincoln Home site just two blocks away.  The house is only open two days a week, from noon to 4:00, since it is operated by a private foundation with docent guides.  Our docent, Connie Sims, was excellent.  The restoration has concentrated on the structure itself, not furniture and furnishings, though a few pieces of original furniture and paintings are on display.  A collection of antique watches is housed in the basement.

I've been a volunteer at the Iles house.  This house is not always open because it is all charity and volunteers.  Iles was a friend and neighbor of Abraham Lincoln and donated property for the Home of the Friendless.  Greatly and lovingly maintained with "Summer Porch Chats" on interesting topics.

A couple blocks south of Lincoln's home is  the Elijah Iles home, the oldest existing home in Springfield. We got there at 11:45 a.m. on a Saturday and had to wait until noon when it opened.  The docent did a great job explaining the history of the home (it has been moved several times before getting to the 7th St. location) and pointing out interesting artifacts within the home including an oil portrait of Elijah Iles, an inlaid table, and a large armoire. Because of my husband's health, we had to cut short our tour of the 1st floor because he really wanted to see the watch and clock collection on the lower level. As we headed down the stairs, I was picturing a cluttered workbench with lots of clock parts piled up.  Was I wrong!  The collection of watches, clocks, and unique time pieces was beautifully arranged on the wall and in glass cases. We watched a short video about the Springfield Watch Co. and then had the pleasure of meeting the elderly gentleman who collected the items.  He, too, was a wealth of information and was obviously pleased to be able to share his knowledge.
What an awesome piece of history is preserved here!!! Tour guides are very knowledgeable about the history of this location and the city!!! Very awesome tour, thank you so much!!!

name: Great Western Depot
reviews: This is definitely worth the visit, just for its place in history. There is a great brochure and video that have Lincoln's farewell speech. There is also a really neat example of a telegraph you can try, which the kids really enjoyed. There are some pictures on the walls, a certificate given to the conductor that transported Lincoln's body and a ticket window. Don't allow much time here, 15 minutes is probably plenty. The downstairs is only open to the public. The upstairs is a law office now. Must see, but don't expect too much here.

This is a historic location for Lincoln Fans.  This is the depot that he departed from to head to Washington for his inauguration.  A large crowd gathered and he addressed them.  There is a marker and this is worth a quick stop while in springfield.

This is definitely worth the visit, just for its place in history. There is a great brochure and video that have Lincoln's farewell speech. There is also a really neat example of a telegraph you can try, which the kids really enjoyed. There are some pictures on the walls, a certificate given to the conductor that transported Lincoln's body and a ticket window. Don't allow much time here, 15 minutes is probably plenty. The downstairs is only open to the public. The upstairs is a law office now. Must see, but don't expect too much here.

This is where Lincoln departed Springfield and headed to DC  - it is full of Presidential history. We went by, found a parking spot, and took some photos - they have two free flyers on a sign out front and it is, as you would expect, literally next to the train tracks. 

There is a cool sign on the building next door which also makes a good photo. 

If you are into Presidential history, this is a must visit.

Go Enjoy!
Memories of Abraham Lincoln on the campaign of 1860. Good video displays. Great building restoration.
The spot at which Lincoln departed Springfield, the last time he set foot there, before he set off for Washington. It's a quick visit here, but a poignant one.
This is an interesting display of model trains.  The entry fee is included with tickets for the Lincoln Museum.

This makes for a quick stop but is part of history.  The outside lends that original look and it is stationed right next to the railroad tracks.  Inside first sit down and watch the film about Lincoln and his movement via train across the states towards Washington where he would begin his term as President.  This stop at Springfield was very emotional for him due to all his friends and neighbors coming out in support and to see him off.  There are some artifacts to look at and read about.  In the center is a metal ticket seller cage.  Can spend a half hour here tops.  Note the mural on the building across the street - cool!

name: Air Combat Museum
reviews: This is a private collection stored in a hangar at the airport.  It has 2 flyable WWII fighters, the Corsair and P51 Mustang, the cockpit section of a MIG 15 that you can sit in, and several other restorable planes of lessor note.  Free, donation is really deserved.  Can be difficult to find, there is just a door with a small sign on the side of a hanger building - see the red circle in the picture.

Great for a rainy day activity.  The kids can actually do hands on with the planes, the two cats are really friendly as mascots out there.  People are friendly too!  Only during the weekdays though so now with school starting make it a school holiday activity.

While planning our two-day tour of Springfield, mostly to visit museums and shrines devoted to Abraham Lincoln, we noticed that there are other museums of a non-Lincoln nature that have been established in Illinois' capital city. One of the most interesting is the Air Combat Museum. Located at Lincoln Airport, it is the dream fulfillment of founder Mike George. It showcases the role of military aviation and features a collection of historic aircraft and aviation memorabilia that dates from World War II to the Vietnam War. As an historian, mostly of the Civil War, I also have an extensive collection of World War II books. So a quick trip to the Air Combat Museum was in order. I'm glad we took the time. George has collected 14 historic aircraft that were used during combat, including a North American P-51D Mustang and a Vought F44-5N Corsair. The museum purchases the aircraft, repairs them if necessary and pilots fly them, many times during air shows. The oldest flying airplane in the museum's hangar is the Mustang, which was built in 1944 and served in Europe during World War II. It was purchased in 1989. It was the most famous fighter plane built by the United States during World War II. It escorted allied bombers all the way to Berlin and back to bases in England. They also escorted B-29s to Japan and back. The Corsair was made famous by Major Greg (Pappy) Boyington, whose exploits were depicted in his book and TV show entitled "Black Sheep Squadron." It helped to ensure the Bent Wing Birds' place in history. The museum also has non-military aircraft, including a Soko G-2 that was one of four similar aircraft used in the 1992 action film "Iron Eagle 3." The museum offers daily tours and welcomes volunteers who paint, clean and rebuild parts of the aircraft. Some even get an opportunity to learn how to fly the aircraft.
Nice collection of rare military collectibles. Easy to find with friendly staff. Strange to see a WWII half-track at an air museum.

This is a private collection stored in a hangar at the airport.  It has 2 flyable WWII fighters, the Corsair and P51 Mustang, the cockpit section of a MIG 15 that you can sit in, and several other restorable planes of lessor note.  Free, donation is really deserved.  Can be difficult to find, there is just a door with a small sign on the side of a hanger building - see the red circle in the picture.

Great for a rainy day activity.  The kids can actually do hands on with the planes, the two cats are really friendly as mascots out there.  People are friendly too!  Only during the weekdays though so now with school starting make it a school holiday activity.
We were greeted by a fellow who was restoring one of the planes  and he gave us a very nice in depth talk about the planes.

This is a great little museum. We visited this past weekend and had a great time viewing all of the aircraft, it even captured the attention of my teenage stepson! They have several military aircraft inside of an aircraft hangar that you can view and read about. The staff member that we met was very knowledgeable about all of them and spent quite a while just chatting about the aircraft with us. It was an educational and enjoyable visit for all of us.

name: The BOS Center
reviews: This beautiful facility also sponsors Cheer Contests, entertainers, kids shows and so much more.  Situated right next to a great hotel the Doubletree now it is so convenient for parking underground, hotel stay too!
With the volume of teenage and young adults in attendance for this event the convention center was organized and the facility was clean.

Over the past 3 years, I have attended our annual Legion convention, I'm impressed each & every year, how accommodating the center has been for our needs.  From educational booths, convention program, & receptions held in the basement, where a food table was available with vegetables, fruit, meat, drinks, etc for a large group.  Employees were able to keep up with empty plates & making sure there was enough food to go around. The only problem I could see, is that it would have been nice to find more seats, since we have a large number of seniors.  The food served was also very good & there didn't seem to be a any complaints.

It's Springfield's convention center and place for concerts, etc. We have been there a few times for various events. I feel it could be a bit larger, but they always manage to do a pretty good job. It's right downtown so no room for expansion.

Attended an event here recently, nothing too impressive but not shabby. Parking directly across the street was adequate and rather inexpensive. Venue was clean and staff helpful. Restroom was large and clean. Concessions were available but we didn't have a need.

name: Rees Memorial Carillon
address: 1740 W Fayette Ave Washington Park - 1740 W. Fayette Avenue
reviews: Be sure to schedule your visit for a time when the exceptionally talented fella will actually be playing the Carillon.  It is outstanding!  Bring a lawn chair, sit and be entertained!  Make sure to step inside and see what it looks like from that side as well!

Be sure to schedule your visit for a time when the exceptionally talented fella will actually be playing the Carillon.  It is outstanding!  Bring a lawn chair, sit and be entertained!  Make sure to step inside and see what it looks like from that side as well!

If you are lucky enough to hear the carillon, you are lucky enough!  The carillon festival is a great opportunity to hear the sounds of different people from all over the world who are experts in playing!  A great family event.  Sometimes at lunch we can catch a beautiful song and what a treat!  Washington Park is the most beautiful park around, with a great playground and great place to walk or ride a bike.  Tennis courts are also on the grounds.  The Botanical Garden and Rose Garden are next to the Carillon.  Take time to see and browse in the beauty!

Try to hit during the Carillon Festival in June but if not they have Christmas time concerts and/or just listen to the bells.  We are very fortunate to have this thanks to a very generous contributor in the past.  One of the best around the world!

I would suggest checking their website before planning your visit. They have music concerts only at certain times. If it rains, they will not have the concert. Your visit will include an elevator ride and watching a video. However you will have amazing views from the top.  When we were there someone was practicing playing and that can only be heard from the inside. If for some reason you go during the times they have tours and it says on the door “will be back,” it’s because they can’t be open while having a tour and will close the doors.  Just wait, might take 30 minutes.

Washington Park is home to a Dutch-cast 67 bell carillon, one of the world's largest, with a 5-1/2 octave range. It was a gift of local newspaper publisher and one-term state senator, Thomas Rees, who fell in love with Carillons while in Europe during World War I.  Housed in a bell tower near the botanical gardens in the park, the Carillon is used for concerts throughout the year.

We happened to be in Springfield at the start of the week-long international festival so decided to attend the first evening's concert. This consisted of alternating carillon and live band performances on a pleasant evening with the park and gardens as a backdrop. The band started with a selection of marches which was followed by the Dutch-born director of the Rees Carillon, Carlo Van Ulft, performing a series of classical selections. The band then returned for another short session and then Lisa Lonie, the resident carillonneur at Princeton University and two Philadelphia area churches, performed.

If you happen to be in the area when they have a concert, be sure to take it in - it is great music and a lot of fun.
Great concerts during annual International Carillon festival. World renown Carilloneurs and a fireworks display icon one night of the many day festival.
I have gone to a few Carillon shows and loved all of them, being in a beautiful setting and hearing the bells is just gorgeous.  A unique experience and gorgeous surroundings, pack a picnic.

name: Hoogland Center for the Arts
reviews: I love it when they have the arts on display and for opening night have a reception with the artists there to talk to you about their work.  We have been inspired to meet new artists and have bought some of their local work.  Also, a great place to see new young talent in the performing arts too.  So lucky to have this downtown!
Fantastic show.  Broadway quality vocals and talent.  Highly recommend attending before this show ends.

This visit was as guests of a company we use. Were not able to choose our seats and ended up with nowhere to put my walker. An older gentleman in a red coat came by and said I could sit a certain place "for now". I sat down on my walker. He later came by and told me I couldn't sit there as I was in the way of the people behind me. He then directed me to a proper place with folding chairs. I again sat on my walker as the chairs were hard and my walker seat is padded.

We thoroughly enjoyed the play and always have a good time when we go. It just seems like they could offer more seating for handicapped. 

Greatly appreciate the elevators and it's a beautiful facility.  Looking forward to our next opportunity to see a play there.
We were in the very back row and we could see and hear everything.  20$, not bad for 3 hours of entertainment.

The Hoogland is such a nice family theater to see great performances by young and older seasoned performers. They even have performances from well known performers. The place is well kept, tickets are not expensive but most of all a friendly environment.

name: Illinois State Fairgrounds
reviews: This years Horse Fair had very little to offer for the equine people. vendors were way down. There were very food vendors or equine venders. Double Dan was the only clinician we enjoyed. The horse fair has went down drastically over the past years and we will probably won't be attending in the future. At least the coliseum was open this year

I stayed here because it is close to the Lincoln history sites.  The Illinois State Fairground Campground is clean and well-kept.  Spaces are tight, especially for RVs with slide-outs. There are full hookups and it is reasonably priced.  During my 3-day stay, a careless employee with a weed eater behind the row of RVs inadvertently tossed a rock into my trailer window.  The window shattered, creating a 7-month logistic and bureaucratic hassle for me.  Illinois State Fairground did step up and take responsibility for the incident and paid for the window replacement.  My suggestion:  If you hear the mowers, stand guard by your RV!

Some of the buildings on the fairgrounds are very historical. I have been to the car derbies, horse shows, the state fair, musical concerts, the farmer’s market, and food shows on these grounds. I am so happy the state fair was a success this year!

I really enjoyed the fair. There were several spots to hear live music, which I love. 
Then you have to see the Butter Cow! Food was reasonably priced and exhibits were free. I didn’t go on rides but they looked fun. Highly recommend a visit there.

We went on a Friday afternoon. It is so much to do and see. When you first arrive it doesn't look like much, but there seems like acres of area to cover. Fun rides, so much food. They even have an Ethnic area with all types of cuisine, Mediterranean, Jamaican, Mexican, Vietnamese, Chinese, Greek and more. The entry cost was $3 for seniors and $5-10 for adults. We primarily wanted to see Snoop Dog, who was on the Grand Stage. It was a nice mix of people. I would recommend it.

name: Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception
reviews: This church is so very beautiful that it is a sight to see just like we traipse over to Italy to see all the Cathedrals there.  Once you are inside look down the aisle, then look up at the very different ceiling.  Walk down front and take in all the beauty of the altar and paintings etc.  Something to see right here in Springfield.
An absolutely beautiful church.  I think the monsignor finally retired,  but I used to really enjoy when he celebrated mass.

This Catholic cathedral was totally restored a few years ago, and the majesty of the interior is stunning.  It is located in downtown Spfld, not far from the Dana-Thomas House, and Incredibly Delicious Bakery (Patrick studied in Paris)!  It's worth the time to visit and go inside, just make sure the church is open first.  This is also the home grounds of Bishop Paprocki.
Attended wedding here and the church is spectacular.  Beautiful wedding. The ceiling and architectural was exquisite. Worth a stop to see it if you like old churches!

Went here for to check out this awesome place of worship!!! What a beautiful Cathedral in the beautiful city of Springfield!!! This place is just beautiful and pictures don't do it justice!!! You have to come here and check out how awesome this Cathedral is!!!
